#Text=2. Cable Model
#Text=2.1. Distributed Parameters of Tunnel-Installed Cables
#Text=The three-phase cable can be regarded as a transmission line system consisting of 6 conductors .

#Text=The propagation characteristics of the voltage and current on the conductors are determined by the distributed impedance matrix Z ( unit : Ω ) and the distributed admittance matrix Y ( unit : S ) .

#Text=The skin effect in the metal sheath is enhanced at high frequencies and the current is bound to the inner surface and outer surface of the sheath , which makes the transfer impedance decrease rapidly and it can be ignored .

#Text=In this case , the distributed parameter matrix Z and Y of the three-phase cable are as follows : ( 1 ) ( 2 ) where zcc , zss , zss , and zmu represent the self-impedance of the inner conductor , self-impedance of the metal sheath , and mutual impedance between the conductors , respectively .

#Text=yss = yse + ycs + 2ymu , where ycs , yse , and ymu are the admittance of the inner conductor , admittance of the metal sheath to the earth , and mutual admittance between the metal sheaths , respectively .
#Text=The formulas to calculate the impedance and admittance of directly buried cables have been given in .

#Text=The calculation of the admittance of tunnel-installed cables is the same , but the self-impedance zs and mutual impedance zm used to obtain the impedances zcc , zss zss , and z mu need to be calculated by Tylavsky ’s high-frequency formulas .
#Text=Figure 2

#Text=shows the structure of the tunnel-installed cables , where R represents the radius of tunnel , b represents the distance from cable to the tunnel center , d represents the center spacing of the cables , θ represents the included angle between two cables , and r 1 , r 2 , and r 3 represent the radius of the inner conductor , insulating layer , and metal sheath respectively .
#Text=In this paper , the unit of all the length variables is meter and that of the angle is rad .

#Text=Then the self-impedance zs and mutual impedance zm of the cable-ground loop are : ( 3 ) ( 4 ) where ρ ( unit : Ω∙m ) and μ e ( no units ) are the resistivity and the relative permeability of the earth respectively , ω ( unit : rad/s ) is the angular frequency , m = ( jωμ e μ 0/ ρ )1/2 and Kn represents the n -th order second modified Bessel function .

#Text=To simplify the calculation , assume that the three cables are completely symmetrical , that is , the structure parameters of each cable are the same , and the distance and angle between any two cables are equal .
#Text=In this case , d and b are represented by the geometric mean distance of the actual distance .
#Text=2.2. Cable Characteristic Admittance Model
#Text=The conductors are coupled to each other in a three-phase cable system , and therefore the voltage and current on each conductor is affected by the voltage and current on other conductors .

#Text=The three-phase cable system can be transformed into a number of independent two-conductor transmission lines by using a modal transformation , then the characteristic admittance matrix Y c can be obtained from the distributed parameter matrix Z and Y : ( 5 ) where λ is the propagation constant matrix of each mode after decoupling and T V is the voltage transformation matrix .
#Text=λ and T V are the eigenvalues and eigenvector matrix derived from the diagonalization of the matrix product ZY , that is : ( 6 )

#Text=Similar to the two-conductor transmission line , the characteristic admittance matrix Y c characterizes the relationship between the voltage and the current on the multi-conductor transmission line .
#Text=Based on the assumption that the cable is completely symmetrical , the extended matrix of the Clarke transform matrix can be used as the voltage transform matrix T V .

#Text=Equations ( 1 ) , ( 2 ) , and ( 6 ) are substituted into Equation ( 5 ) and simplified to obtain Yc : ( 7 ) where : ( 8 ) ( 9 ) ( 10 ) where Ycs is the coaxial characteristic admittance , namely , the reciprocal of the characteristic impedance of a single coaxial cable .
#Text=Ycs is only related to the structure of the cable , usually between 0 . 025 S and 0.1 S.
#Text=Yse is the characteristic admittance between the cable sheath and the earth , and Yss is the characteristic admittance between the sheaths of the cable .
#Text=Yse and Yss are affected by the external environment of the cable system .
#Text=If Yc is regarded as a nodal admittance matrix , it can be expressed in the form of self-admittance and mutual admittance , as shown in
